Front: [Smooth muscle] Main locations of smooth muscle in the body?
Back: In walls of hollow organs except the heart: blood vessels, airways, stomach, intestines, bladder, uterus, and passageways of the circulatory, respiratory, digestive, and reproductive systems.

Front: [Smooth muscle] What is the major muscular exception to smooth muscle in hollow organs?
Back: The heart, which contains cardiac muscle instead of smooth muscle.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Orientation and function of the longitudinal smooth muscle layer?
Back: Fibers run parallel to the organ long axis; contraction shortens the organ length.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Orientation and function of the circular smooth muscle layer?
Back: Fibers run around the organ; contraction constricts the lumen diameter.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Compare smooth muscle layer orientation in GI tract vs ureter.
Back: GI tract: inner circular, outer longitudinal. Ureter: inner longitudinal, outer circular.

Front: [Smooth muscle] How many layers of smooth muscle does the stomach have?
Back: Three layers of smooth muscle.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Basic cell morphology and control of smooth muscle?
Back: Spindle shaped cells with a single central nucleus, no striations, and involuntary control.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Typical size of a smooth muscle cell?
Back: Length about 30 to 200 micrometers and diameter about 5 to 10 micrometers.

Front: [Smooth muscle] What connective tissue sheath does smooth muscle have?
Back: Only an endomysium; it lacks perimysium and epimysium connective tissue sheaths.

Front: [Smooth muscle] What are varicosities and diffuse junctions in smooth muscle?
Back: Varicosities are bulbous swellings of autonomic nerve fibers that release neurotransmitter into wide synaptic clefts called diffuse junctions.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Role of caveolae in smooth muscle sarcolemma?
Back: Pouchlike infoldings of the sarcolemma that contain many calcium channels and help with extracellular calcium entry.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Compare smooth muscle SR and T tubules to skeletal muscle.
Back: Smooth muscle has a less developed sarcoplasmic reticulum and lacks T tubules.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Are thick and thin filaments arranged in sarcomeres in smooth muscle?
Back: No, thick and thin filaments are present but not arranged in sarcomeres, so there are no striations.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Special feature of thick filaments in smooth muscle vs skeletal?
Back: Smooth muscle thick filaments have myosin heads along their entire length, allowing interaction over a larger range of cell lengths.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Ratio of thick to thin filaments in smooth vs skeletal muscle?
Back: Smooth muscle: about 1 thick to 13 thin. Skeletal muscle: about 1 thick to 2 thin.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Regulatory proteins: what is absent in smooth muscle and what is present?
Back: Smooth muscle lacks troponin, has tropomyosin that does not block actin binding sites, and uses calmodulin instead for calcium binding and regulation.

Front: [Smooth muscle] What structures anchor thin filaments in smooth muscle and what links them?
Back: Dense bodies anchor thin filaments and intermediate filaments connect dense bodies to each other, forming a cytoskeletal network.

Front: [Smooth muscle] What is unitary (visceral) smooth muscle and where is it found?
Back: A type of smooth muscle found in all hollow organs except the heart, arranged in opposing sheets, with cells electrically coupled and contracting as a unit.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Key properties of unitary smooth muscle (innervation and electrical coupling)?
Back: Innervated by varicosities, often has spontaneous action potentials, cells are electrically coupled by gap junctions, and the tissue contracts as a functional syncytium.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Define slow wave potentials vs pacemaker potentials in smooth muscle.
Back: Slow wave potentials are cyclic depolarizations and repolarizations that may not reach threshold; pacemaker potentials are spontaneous depolarizations that always reach threshold and trigger action potentials.

Front: [Smooth muscle] What is multiunit smooth muscle and where is it located?
Back: Smooth muscle organized as individual fibers each with its own motor neuron terminal, few gap junctions, not self excitatory; found in large airways, large arteries, arrector pili muscles, and the iris.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Electrical and functional behavior of multiunit smooth muscle?
Back: It has few gap junctions, does not show spontaneous depolarizations, and produces graded contractions in response to neural input rather than unitary contractions.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Describe the intermediate filament lattice and dense bodies in smooth muscle.
Back: Intermediate filaments and dense bodies form a lattice that transmits tension to the sarcolemma; dense bodies anchor intermediate filaments to the membrane and within the cytoplasm and can form adherence junctions between cells.

Front: [Smooth muscle] How does filament arrangement produce the characteristic contraction shape of smooth muscle?
Back: Thick and thin filaments are arranged diagonally so contraction produces a corkscrew shape of the cell rather than straight shortening.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Why can smooth muscle contract effectively when greatly stretched?
Back: Myosin heads on each side of the thick filament are oriented in opposite directions, so thin filaments on either side can slide in opposite directions and still generate force over a wide length range.

Front: [Smooth muscle] Sequence of events in smooth muscle contraction starting from calcium entry.
Back: Calcium influx from extracellular space and SR increases cytoplasmic calcium, calcium binds calmodulin, the calcium calmodulin complex activates myosin light chain kinase, which phosphorylates myosin light chains, activating myosin ATPase so myosin binds actin and cross bridge cycling produces contraction.

Front: [Smooth muscle] How does smooth muscle relaxation occur at the molecular level?
Back: Calcium is pumped back out of the cell and into the SR, decreasing cytosolic calcium, and myosin light chain phosphatase dephosphorylates myosin light chains, reducing cross bridge cycling and leading to relaxation.

Front: [Smooth muscle] What is the latch bridge mechanism in smooth muscle?
Back: A state where myosin heads remain attached to actin for prolonged periods with little ATP use, allowing smooth muscle to maintain tension with low energy expenditure.

Front: [Homeostasis] What is meant by a regulated variable in homeostasis?
Back: A variable for which the body has a sensor and a set point and that is actively maintained near that set point by homeostatic control mechanisms.

Front: [Homeostasis] What is meant by a non regulated variable in homeostasis?
Back: A variable that is not directly sensed and controlled to a specific set point, but typically remains within a normal range over time, for example heart rate.

Front: [Homeostasis] Define set point, sensor, error detector, integrating center, and effector in a homeostatic control system.
Back: Set point: desired value of a regulated variable. Sensor: detector of the current value. Error detector: compares sensor input to set point. Integrating center: determines the appropriate response. Effector: executes the response to restore the variable toward the set point.

Front: [Homeostasis] Distinguish negative feedback from positive feedback with examples.
Back: Negative feedback returns a variable toward its set point, for example body temperature control. Positive feedback amplifies a response and drives the system away from the set point, for example blood clotting or uterine contractions during childbirth.

Front: [Homeostasis] What is feedforward control and give an example.
Back: A control mechanism that anticipates a change and initiates responses in advance, for example salivation and digestive secretions when smelling food before ingestion.

Front: [ANS] Main effectors of the autonomic nervous system?
Back: Smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, and glands.

Front: [ANS] General functions of the autonomic nervous system in supporting body activities.
Back: It adjusts functions subconsciously by shunting blood to active areas, adjusting heart rate, blood pressure, digestive activity, and pupil size to ensure optimal support for body activities.

Front: [ANS] How does the somatic nervous system efferent pathway differ from the autonomic pathway?
Back: Somatic: one neuron from CNS to skeletal muscle, thick myelinated axon, always excitatory and uses acetylcholine. Autonomic: two neuron chain, preganglionic neuron in CNS with lightly myelinated axon to a ganglion, postganglionic neuron with unmyelinated axon to effector, can be excitatory or inhibitory and releases acetylcholine or norepinephrine.

Front: [ANS] Define preganglionic and postganglionic neurons in the ANS.
Back: Preganglionic neuron has its cell body in the CNS and sends a thin lightly myelinated axon to an autonomic ganglion where it releases acetylcholine. Postganglionic neuron has its cell body in the ganglion and sends an unmyelinated axon to the effector, releasing acetylcholine or norepinephrine.

Front: [ANS] Main functional role of the parasympathetic division vs the sympathetic division.
Back: Parasympathetic promotes maintenance functions and conserves energy, rest and digest. Sympathetic mobilizes the body during activity, fight or flight.

Front: [ANS] What is dual innervation and why is it important?
Back: Most viscera receive both sympathetic and parasympathetic fibers, which usually have opposite effects, allowing fine control of organ function by shifting the balance between the two divisions.

Front: [ANS] What is parasympathetic tone and where does it dominate?
Back: A basal level of parasympathetic activity that dominates the heart and smooth muscle of digestive and urinary tracts, slowing heart rate and setting normal activity levels of digestive and urinary systems.

Front: [ANS] Name structures that receive only sympathetic innervation and list two unique sympathetic functions.
Back: Only sympathetic: adrenal medulla, sweat glands, arrector pili muscles, kidneys, and most blood vessels. Unique functions include thermoregulation via sweat and arteriole diameter, renin release from kidneys, and metabolic effects such as increasing blood glucose and mobilizing fats.

Front: [ANS] Why are parasympathetic effects usually localized and short lived compared to sympathetic effects?
Back: Parasympathetic neurotransmitter acetylcholine is quickly destroyed by acetylcholinesterase, limiting effects, whereas sympathetic norepinephrine is inactivated more slowly and adrenal medulla hormones circulate in blood, producing longer lasting and more diffuse effects.

Front: [ANS] Three main levels of central control of the ANS.
Back: Hypothalamus, brain stem, and spinal cord.

Front: [ANS] Major ANS functions controlled by the hypothalamus.
Back: Heart rate, blood pressure, body temperature, water balance, endocrine activity, and emotional autonomic responses.

Front: [ANS] Give two examples of ANS related disorders and the division involved.
Back: Hypertension: often due to overactive sympathetic vasoconstrictor responses. Some ulcers: can result from overactive parasympathetic activity that alters blood flow and acid secretion in the stomach lining.

Front: [Endocrine] Define a hormone.
Back: A chemical messenger secreted into extracellular fluid and transported in the blood to regulate the activity of target cells at a distance.

Front: [Endocrine] Distinguish endocrine and exocrine glands with examples.
Back: Endocrine glands are ductless and release hormones into the blood, for example pituitary or thyroid. Exocrine glands have ducts and secrete onto body surfaces or into cavities, for example sweat or salivary glands.

Front: [Endocrine] Two major chemical classes of hormones and solubility properties.
Back: Amino acid based hormones are generally water soluble and cannot cross the plasma membrane, acting via surface receptors and second messengers. Steroid hormones are lipid soluble, cross the membrane, and act via intracellular receptors and direct gene activation.

Front: [Endocrine] Give examples of amino acid based hormones and of steroid hormones.
Back: Amino acid based: amines like epinephrine and norepinephrine, peptides such as ADH and oxytocin, proteins such as insulin and growth hormone. Steroid: gonadal hormones such as estrogen and testosterone, and adrenocortical hormones such as cortisol and aldosterone.

Front: [Endocrine] List the five key steps of the cAMP second messenger signaling pathway.
Back: Hormone binds its receptor, receptor activates G protein, G protein activates adenylate cyclase, adenylate cyclase converts ATP to cAMP, cAMP activates protein kinases that phosphorylate target proteins to produce a cellular response.

Front: [Endocrine] How can cAMP signaling lead to activation of transcription?
Back: cAMP activates protein kinase A, which can enter the nucleus and phosphorylate transcription factors that bind DNA and promote transcription of specific genes.

Front: [Endocrine] Outline the DAG IP3 pathway leading to PKC activation.
Back: Hormone binds receptor and activates G protein, which activates phospholipase C. Phospholipase C splits PIP2 into DAG and IP3. DAG activates protein kinase C, while IP3 triggers calcium release from the endoplasmic reticulum, and calcium can further activate PKC.

Front: [Endocrine] Mechanism of action of lipid soluble steroid hormones.
Back: Steroid hormone diffuses through the plasma membrane and binds an intracellular receptor. The hormone receptor complex binds hormone response elements on DNA, initiating transcription to mRNA, which is translated into proteins that mediate the response.

Front: [Endocrine] Three major types of stimuli for hormone release with one example each.
Back: Humoral: changes in blood ions or nutrients, for example low blood calcium stimulating parathyroid hormone. Neural: nerve fibers stimulating hormone release, for example sympathetic input to the adrenal medulla. Hormonal: hormones from one gland stimulating another, for example hypothalamic releasing hormones acting on the anterior pituitary.

Front: [Endocrine] Three factors that determine target cell activation by a hormone.
Back: Blood concentration of the hormone, number of receptors on the target cell, and the affinity between hormone and receptor.

Front: [Endocrine] How do water soluble and lipid soluble hormones differ in circulation and half life?
Back: Water soluble hormones circulate freely in plasma and generally have short half lives of minutes. Lipid soluble steroid and thyroid hormones circulate bound to plasma proteins and have longer half lives ranging from hours to days.

Front: [Endocrine] Name the two lobes of the pituitary and their basic tissue type and function.
Back: Anterior pituitary or adenohypophysis is glandular tissue that synthesizes and secretes hormones. Posterior pituitary or neurohypophysis is neural tissue that stores and releases hormones made by the hypothalamus.

Front: [Endocrine] How is the anterior pituitary functionally connected to the hypothalamus?
Back: By the hypophyseal portal system: hypothalamic neurosecretory cells secrete releasing and inhibiting hormones into a primary capillary plexus, these travel through portal veins to the anterior pituitary, which then adjusts its hormone secretion into a secondary capillary plexus.

Front: [Endocrine] List the main hypothalamic releasing or inhibiting hormones mentioned.
Back: Growth hormone releasing and inhibiting factors, somatostatin, thyrotropin releasing hormone, corticotropin releasing hormone, gonadotropin releasing hormone, and prolactin inhibiting hormone dopamine.

Front: [Endocrine] List the six major anterior pituitary hormones and one main function of each.
Back: Growth hormone stimulates body growth, protein synthesis, and fat metabolism. Thyroid stimulating hormone stimulates thyroid hormone release. Adrenocorticotropic hormone stimulates adrenal cortex corticosteroids. Follicle stimulating hormone stimulates gamete production. Luteinizing hormone stimulates ovulation and testosterone production. Prolactin stimulates milk production.

Front: [Endocrine] Which anterior pituitary hormone does not use cAMP as a second messenger in this course?
Back: Growth hormone.

Front: [Blood] Define hematocrit and give typical values for males vs females.
Back: Hematocrit is the percentage of blood volume occupied by red blood cells, typically about 45 percent overall, about 47 percent in males and 42 percent in females depending on the source.

Front: [Blood] What are the three major components when a blood sample is centrifuged?
Back: Plasma on top, buffy coat in the middle containing leukocytes and platelets, and erythrocytes at the bottom forming the hematocrit.

Front: [Blood] Major plasma proteins and their primary functions.
Back: Albumin maintains osmotic pressure and transports substances. Globulins transport lipids and fat soluble vitamins and some are antibodies. Fibrinogen is important for blood clotting.

Front: [Blood] Why are erythrocytes well suited for gas transport?
Back: They are biconcave for high surface area, have no mitochondria so they use anaerobic metabolism and do not consume oxygen they carry, and are mostly filled with hemoglobin for gas binding.

Front: [Blood] Define oxyhemoglobin, deoxyhemoglobin, and carbaminohemoglobin.
Back: Oxyhemoglobin is hemoglobin bound to oxygen in the lungs, deoxyhemoglobin is hemoglobin after releasing oxygen to tissues, and carbaminohemoglobin is hemoglobin with carbon dioxide bound to the globin portion, carrying about 20 percent of blood carbon dioxide.

Front: [Blood] Where does hematopoiesis occur in adults and what is the stem cell?
Back: It occurs in red bone marrow myeloid tissue and all formed elements derive from the hematopoietic stem cell called the hemocytoblast.

Front: [Blood] List the main stages of erythropoiesis from stem cell to mature erythrocyte.
Back: Hematopoietic stem cell to myeloid stem cell to proerythroblast to basophilic erythroblast to polychromatic erythroblast to orthochromatic erythroblast to reticulocyte to mature erythrocyte.

Front: [Blood] What is the role of erythropoietin and its main site of production?
Back: Erythropoietin stimulates erythropoiesis and is mainly produced by the kidneys in response to hypoxia, with some contribution from the liver.

Front: [Blood] Nutritional requirements for effective erythropoiesis.
Back: Adequate supplies of amino acids, lipids, and carbohydrates, iron for hemoglobin synthesis, and vitamin B12 and folic acid for DNA synthesis in rapidly dividing precursor cells.

Front: [Blood] Typical lifespan of an erythrocyte and fate of its components after destruction.
Back: Lifespan is about 100 to 120 days. Macrophages, mainly in the spleen, phagocytose old cells. Iron is stored and reused, heme is degraded to bilirubin and excreted in bile, and globin is broken down to amino acids.

Front: [Blood] Define anemia in general terms and name three broad causes.
Back: Anemia is a condition with decreased oxygen carrying capacity of the blood. Causes include low red blood cell number, low hemoglobin content, or abnormal hemoglobin.

Front: [Blood] What is polycythemia and one danger it poses?
Back: Polycythemia is an abnormal excess of red blood cells that increases blood viscosity, which can impair blood flow and strain the heart.

Front: [Blood] Origin and basic function of platelets.
Back: Platelets form from fragmentation of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow. They are cell fragments that help form temporary plugs in damaged blood vessels and participate in clotting.

Front: [Blood] Three major steps of hemostasis.
Back: Vascular spasm where vessels constrict, platelet plug formation where platelets adhere to collagen and each other, and coagulation where fibrin reinforces the plug and blood is converted to a gel.

Front: [Blood] What is von Willebrand factor and its role in hemostasis?
Back: A large multimeric protein produced by megakaryocytes and endothelial cells that binds to exposed collagen in damaged vessels and helps platelets adhere to the site of injury.

Front: [Blood] What triggers the intrinsic pathway vs the extrinsic pathway of coagulation?
Back: Intrinsic pathway is triggered by negatively charged surfaces such as activated platelets or exposed collagen and uses factors already present in blood. Extrinsic pathway is triggered by tissue factor from damaged tissues outside the blood.

Front: [Blood] In coagulation, what common step is marked by activated factor X?
Back: Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways converge at activation of factor X, which helps form the prothrombin activator complex.

Front: [Blood] Briefly describe clot retraction.
Back: Platelet actin and myosin contract, pulling on fibrin strands, shrinking the clot, squeezing out serum, and drawing damaged vessel edges together while growth factors stimulate repair.

Front: [Blood] How is fibrinolysis initiated and what enzyme actually digests the clot?
Back: Plasminogen trapped in the clot is converted to plasmin by tissue plasminogen activator, and plasmin enzymatically digests fibrin, dissolving the clot.

Front: [Blood] Mechanisms that normally limit clot growth to the site of damage.
Back: Rapid blood flow removes and dilutes clotting factors, natural inhibitors inactivate activated factors, fibrin binds and localizes thrombin, and antithrombin III with heparin inactivates circulating thrombin.

Front: [Blood] Define thrombus, embolus, and pulmonary embolism.
Back: A thrombus is a clot that develops in an unbroken vessel and may block blood flow. An embolus is a free floating clot fragment. A pulmonary embolism is an embolus that lodges in pulmonary vessels and impairs oxygenation.

Front: [Blood] Major bleeding disorders caused by low platelets, impaired liver, and factor deficiencies.
Back: Thrombocytopenia is low platelet count. Impaired liver function reduces production of clotting factors. Hemophilias are hereditary deficiencies of specific clotting factors such as VIII, IX, or XI.

Front: [Blood] Basic ABO blood group antigens and antibodies for type A, B, AB, and O.
Back: Type A has A antigens and anti B antibodies. Type B has B antigens and anti A antibodies. Type AB has both A and B antigens and no anti A or anti B antibodies universal recipient. Type O has no A or B antigens and both anti A and anti B antibodies universal donor for red cells.

Front: [Blood] What is erythroblastosis fetalis and how is it prevented?
Back: A hemolytic disease in an Rh negative mother carrying an Rh positive fetus after sensitization, where maternal anti Rh antibodies attack fetal red blood cells. It is prevented by giving RhoGAM, anti Rh antibodies, to the mother to prevent her immune system from becoming sensitized.

Front: [Heart] Name and briefly describe the two main circulatory circuits of the heart.
Back: Pulmonary circuit: right heart pumps deoxygenated blood to the lungs for oxygenation and carbon dioxide removal. Systemic circuit: left heart pumps oxygenated blood to the body to deliver oxygen and nutrients and remove wastes.

Front: [Heart] Define artery and vein in terms of blood flow, not oxygen content.
Back: Arteries carry blood away from the heart. Veins carry blood toward the heart, regardless of oxygenation level.

Front: [Heart] Which heart layers correspond to pericardium, myocardium, and endocardium?
Back: Pericardium is the outer double walled sac including fibrous and serous layers. Myocardium is the thick middle cardiac muscle layer responsible for contraction. Endocardium is the inner endothelial lining of chambers and valves.

Front: [Heart] Two main types of heart valves and their function.
Back: Atrioventricular valves between atria and ventricles prevent backflow into atria. Semilunar valves between ventricles and great arteries prevent backflow into ventricles.

Front: [Heart] Explain the role of chordae tendineae and papillary muscles.
Back: Chordae tendineae anchor AV valve cusps to papillary muscles, which contract during ventricular systole to hold the cusps closed and prevent eversion into the atria.

Front: [Heart] What produces the two main heart sounds lub and dub?
Back: Lub is closure of the atrioventricular valves at the start of ventricular systole. Dub is closure of the semilunar valves at the start of ventricular diastole.

Front: [Heart] Basic route of blood through the pulmonary circuit from systemic veins back to heart and lungs.
Back: Deoxygenated blood returns via superior vena cava, inferior vena cava, and coronary sinus to the right atrium, passes through the tricuspid valve to the right ventricle, then through the pulmonary semilunar valve into the pulmonary trunk and pulmonary arteries leading to the lungs.

Front: [Heart] Basic route of blood through the systemic circuit from lungs to body.
Back: Oxygenated blood returns from the lungs via pulmonary veins to the left atrium, passes through the mitral valve to the left ventricle, then through the aortic semilunar valve into the aorta and systemic arteries to the body.

Front: [Heart] What is coronary circulation and when is blood mainly delivered to the myocardium?
Back: The coronary circulation is the functional blood supply to the heart muscle via coronary arteries and cardiac veins, and blood is mainly delivered to the myocardium when the heart is relaxed during diastole.

Front: [Heart] Structural features of cardiac muscle cells and intercalated discs.
Back: Cardiac myocytes are striated, short, branched cells with one central nucleus and many mitochondria. Intercalated discs connect cells and contain desmosomes that hold cells together and gap junctions that allow electrical coupling for a functional syncytium.

Front: [Heart] Distinguish contractile cells from pacemaker cells in the heart.
Back: Contractile cells are about 99 percent of cardiac muscle and generate force for pumping. Pacemaker cells about 1 percent are noncontractile autorhythmic cells that spontaneously depolarize and initiate and distribute impulses through the conduction system.

Front: [Heart] List the main components of the intrinsic cardiac conduction system in order of activation.
Back: Sinoatrial node, atrioventricular node with a brief delay, atrioventricular bundle bundle of His, right and left bundle branches, and Purkinje fibers throughout the ventricles.

Front: [Heart] Describe the three phases of the pacemaker cell action potential.
Back: Pacemaker potential is a slow depolarization due to sodium influx and reduced potassium efflux. Depolarization occurs when calcium channels open at threshold and calcium influx drives the upstroke. Repolarization occurs as calcium channels close and potassium channels open, allowing potassium efflux to bring the membrane potential back down.

Front: [Heart] What does the P wave, QRS complex, and T wave represent on an ECG?
Back: The P wave represents atrial depolarization from the sinoatrial node. The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization, while atrial repolarization is hidden. The T wave represents ventricular repolarization.

Front: [Heart] Define systole, diastole, and cardiac cycle.
Back: Systole is the period of contraction, diastole is the period of relaxation, and the cardiac cycle is all events associated with blood flow through the heart during one complete heartbeat, including both atrial and ventricular systole and diastole.

Front: [Heart] Describe ventricular filling phase of the cardiac cycle and define EDV.
Back: During mid to late diastole the atrioventricular valves are open and about 80 percent of ventricular filling is passive, followed by atrial systole adding the remaining volume. End diastolic volume EDV is the volume of blood in each ventricle at the end of ventricular diastole, about 120 milliliters.

Front: [Heart] What is isovolumetric contraction and when does it occur?
Back: A brief phase at the start of ventricular systole when ventricles contract with all valves closed, so pressure rises sharply but no blood is ejected yet.

Front: [Heart] Define stroke volume and give its formula.
Back: Stroke volume is the volume of blood pumped by one ventricle per beat, calculated as end diastolic volume minus end systolic volume.

Front: [Heart] Define cardiac output and give normal resting value in an adult.
Back: Cardiac output is the volume of blood pumped by each ventricle per minute, equal to heart rate times stroke volume. A typical resting value is about 5 liters per minute.

Front: [Heart] Define preload, contractility, and afterload in relation to stroke volume.
Back: Preload is the degree of stretch of ventricular muscle at the end of diastole. Contractility is the intrinsic strength of contraction at a given fiber length. Afterload is the pressure the ventricle must overcome to eject blood, mainly arterial pressure.

Front: [Heart] How does increased venous return affect stroke volume according to the Frank Starling law?
Back: Increased venous return increases end diastolic volume and stretches ventricular fibers, which increases force of contraction and stroke volume according to the Frank Starling law of the heart.

Front: [Heart] How does sympathetic stimulation affect heart rate and contractility?
Back: Sympathetic activity releases norepinephrine onto beta one receptors, increasing the rate of pacemaker depolarization and heart rate and increasing calcium entry into cardiac myocytes, which enhances contractility.

Front: [Heart] Effect of parasympathetic vagal activity on heart rate and what is vagal tone?
Back: Parasympathetic activity via the vagus nerve releases acetylcholine, which opens potassium channels and hyperpolarizes pacemaker cells, slowing heart rate. Vagal tone is the resting parasympathetic influence that maintains a typical resting heart rate around 75 beats per minute.
